history.content: Have you reached out to the faculty or head TAs for the class, or just submitted the application online?

children.subject: I'm hoping a head TA, faculty, or someone who has been hired for these classes will answer, but I certainly think it would help. I receive at least 100 each of the Reader and Tutor applications for each of these classes, so I think doing something to stand out it almost necessary.
This doesn't make sense and it is unfair, since it is not officially announced in the eecs website.
I added to the student response. Hopefully that helps! Nicole sends us the applications and we do review them all.
For any job, reaching out to the person(s) doing the hiring can be incredibly helpful. It shows initiative and enthusiasm for the role.

That's something that anyone can do. So do you suggest that hundreds of potential readers, tutors and GSIs should together with their applications email the staff to express their enthusiasm? Just make this an official announcement then, because what makes sense for a lot of people is that just filling the application is sufficient (and of course not because they don't have any enthusiasm to express, but because they respect other people and the hiring process), but it seems that it doesn't work this way.
I only submitted the application online, are we supposed to reach out to head TA's as well?

history.content:
For hiring, we reviewed all of the applications. However, it becomes very hard to decide if we have no idea who you are besides what we see on the paper because we get a lot of qualified applicants and have few spots.

What helps is if you actively participated in the course, did a great job, TAs saw you help your peers, you have actively reached out to become a reader or academic intern, etc.

On top of that, we're still refining our process so this semester will be different from last and when it comes time to hiring, we'll send out internal forms on top of the official EECS application.

As always, feel free to email me (my email is on the 16B course website http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee16b/sp17/) if you want to express interest in being a reader or assisting in lab, or if you want to know more about what each job entails. 

- Rachel (EE16B co-head TA)

For hiring, we reviewed all of the applications. However, it becomes very hard to decide if we have no idea who you are besides what we see on the paper because we get a lot of qualified applicants and have few spots.

What helps is if you actively participated in the course, did a great job, TAs saw you help your peers, you have actively reached out to become a reader or academic intern, etc.

On top of that, we're still refining our process so this semester will be different from last and when it comes time to hiring, we'll send out internal forms on top of the official EECS application.

As always, feel free to email me (my email is on the 16B course website http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee16b/sp17/) if you want to express interest in being a reader or assisting in lab, or if you want to know more about what each job entails.
Rachel from 16B here -- send me an email (my email is on the course website). I'll write a better piazza answer when I'm not in class.
Rachel from 16B here -- send me an email (my email is on the course website). I'll write a response when I'm not in class.

children.subject: For 16B, we did not send out a form. This will be changing this upcoming semester.
But then how were qualities beyond those on the department application form assessed this semester?
Probably weren't; most courses don't do this.
So was there no internal form this semester? I did not receive one

history.content:
For the past two semesters including this one, I applied to be a reader for EE16A and EE16B and have only received opportunities to be a lab assistant last semester, and did not hear back at all this semester.

I am an upperclassmen who has taken EE16AB, 105, 120 (and done well) and currently taking more EE classes, so I am more than qualified for the position, at least in terms of courses. 

I would really like to be a reader for 16A/B before I graduate, any advice on how to increase my chances of getting an offer next semester, or what 16A/B specifically looks for in their reader selection criteria?
history.subject: How to become a reader for 16A/B??
